reviewText:
As title says Cute Things Dying Violently, but its more then that.
Very cute and funny puzzle game, where your goal is to save at least one creature, sometimes you will have to sacrfice one or more to save the rest, but life is a bi**h.

Gameplay is very addictive, somewhere close to Angry Birds. Fun guaranteed.
Great ammount  of levels, each unique and harder then one before, with each set of levels completed comes juicy boss fight.
Another + is level editor and new levels coming out every week so you dont get bored ^^
Nothing special to say about graphic and sound, its just ok for this type of game.
Game is easy to get and start playing for beginers, but will require a skill to master it.

Overall:
A fun casual game with reasonable price, will give you enough of good play time for that money.
Recommended to everyone above age of 10
voteText: 26 of 36 people (72%) found this review helpful 5 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Death By Buzzsaw

Cute Things Dying Violently is a game where the player may choose to rescue cute critters. These are the types of critters that one would expect to find wandering around aimlessly in a flower bed, through grassy planes, or even in a lightly wooded forest area. However, as I said, the player has a choice, and that choice may lead the player into causing a certain and painful death. Either intentionally, or even quite possibly accidentally. The player may choose to throw these critters onto spikes, into fire hazards, within a bolt of lightning, cause death due to falling, or the player’s choice of small to large buzzsaws can be utilized as well. I really think the developer watched one too many “Saw” movies.

Cute Things Dying Violently is created by ApathyWorks. The game has 60 pre-designed levels. However, with the integration of Steam Workshop and a Level Editor, the potential amount of levels is pretty limitless. This game is heavily integrated onto the Steam PC platform, and as such it also possesses Steam Trading Cards and Steam Achievements. The developer truly went all in, on the Steam platform. Another nice feature is the weekly challenge through the level of the week format from the main menu.

Click the link below to read the full Review:
http://www.gamerheadlines.com/reviews/cute-things-dying-violently/

reviewText:
Flick cute little critters around the place. Sacrifice them to make way for others. Or just inevitably misplace your throw and horribly murder some of them.
Critters swear at you under their breath with their high-pitched voices.
Contains many vulgar but funny jokes.

But seriously, this is a great puzzle/physics/action game that feels a lot like Lemmings. No, it's not mindless murder, the goal is actually to save as many critters as you can, with careful planning and agile execution - by moving and throwing them with interesting interactions with the environment and the gadgets that it contains.

★★★★★★★☆☆☆

reviewText:
Game provided for free for review purpose
Cute Things Dying Violently
Developer: ApathyWorks, LLC
http://store.steampowered.com/app/305820
Price:
CAN $3.29
US  $2.99
EN  £1.99
EU  €2.99
AUS $2.99

This game has an Angry Bird feel to it but is still different from it, it is for casual gamers adn I am pretty sure most of them will love this game. The controls are easy, left click to move your critter around, right click to throw it.

I really suggest that you choose the inverted option because if your critters are on too low, you won`t be able to have them fly hard enough, it takes a little while to

adjust moving your cursor up to have them go up I must say but it will make your life so much easier.

Game play is basic, you need to save at least 1 critter to beat the level, to do this, they must enter the elevator waiting for them. Sounds easy right? Not so fast. You will find obstacle blocking your path, buzzsaw, fire, solid block, spikes. You will have to use switches, springs and everything not tied down to help you get out.

For achievement hunters, you`ll find 23 of them and to get that mischievous complete game, you will have to ace all of the levels in this game, I.E. complete each level with the minimum death allowed.

Just because of that, there is replay ability and on top of that, you get a Level of the week and Steam Workshop support to add player created levels.Level editor is also in the game so no need to download another app to do it.

Final thought: If you like this genre of game, get it and you`ll be happy with your purchase.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U_YVG0XruCM&feature=youtu.be&ab_channel=bobv702000

reviewText:
A decent puzzle game where you try and flick things to the exit. The closest thing I can think of is a cross of lemmings and golf.

It's annoying that there isn't a setting to keep the mouse cursor inside the window in windowed mode. Once your cursor moves outside your flick gets messed up so you need to up the sensitivity and try to keep your mouse inside when flicking. And because they don't let you move the camera the objects are almost always near the edge of the screen.

Non-16:9 resolution options are 'broken' in the sense that you can't move the camera so parts of the screen are cut off. It only matters in the wider stages. For example, in stage 2-3 you can't see the button that will stop the fan (so the level is impossible). For another example, in stage 2-7 the creature can walk offscreen and part of a button is offscreen).

The aim trajectory guide isn't 100% accurate but is passable. However, it can get really terrible in certain circumstances.

In order to unlock the next set of puzzles, you're forced to complete all 7 and then beat the boss (level 8). I think that requirement shouldn't be there or it should be relaxed (complete half the puzzles and boss to progress). It's a puzzle game so it's easy to gate people from seeing all the mechanics that are introduced. There are a lot of things introduced in the second set and I'm guessing a lot of casual puzzle players will have trouble. There are six sets of 8 puzzles to try in the main mode so if you get stuck on a puzzle on the second set you miss out on over half the game. They offer 'level of the week' and user-made levels so if you can't progress at least you can try alternative levels.

I'm not really a fan of puzzle games but if you want a more polished game that has a similar basic premise (get the guy to the exit), you can try something like Eets Munchies. However, I'm not sure there is another game that does this exact premise. If you like the premise but care about any of the problems above you may want to wait for an update. These problems seem like they could be fixable so you might want to wait and see if the developer changes anything.

reviewText:
Reasonably promising Lemmings/Angry Birds hybrid which suffers from iffy mouse control...

In windowed mode, it's easy to move the mouse outside and lose control.  In full-screen, it's still sometimes difficult to grab things - and some levels require you do with with considerable precision.

It's clearly been designed with touch-screens in-mind - but it doesn't seem to recognize Windows touch devices and sticks with mouse controls even on those

So hard to recommend then...
